CreditLine: Promised gift of John and Berthe Ford
Description:
The black protector Mahakala holds a skull cup in his left hand and a curved knife in his right. The enemies whose organs he severs with his knife can be regarded as both living in the world and existing only in our heads (as does, for instance, the notion of unique individuality).

The small figure at the center of the top is the Buddha Vajradhara, who revealed the teaching to the mahasiddha on his right. It was then passed down through time by the lamas who appear on the top row.

Mahakala was a Buddhist transformation of the Hindu Bhairava (a form of the god Shiva), appearing in a cremation ground. One of Bhairava's names was Mahakala (Great Black One, or Great Time, as in "your time has come").

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Albuquerque Museum, Albuquerque; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham. 2001-2003.

Provenance: Lionel Fournier, Grasse, France [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore, Winter 1987, by purchase.
Title: Mahakala and Retinue and Sakya Lineage
